Cofactors

A cofactor is a minor with a sign attached. The appropriate sign comes from the pattern of signs appropriate to a \(3\times 3\) array: \[\begin{bmatrix}+&-&+\\ -&+&-\\ +&-&+\end{bmatrix}\] (i.e. positive signs on the leading diagonal and the signs "alternate" everywhere else.)

Each entry of a matrix \(A\) has a cofactor associated with it. The cofactor of entry \(a_{11}\) is denoted by \(A_{11}\), that of \(a_{23}\) by \(A_{23}\) and so on.

To obtain the cofactor of an element of a \(3\times 3\) matrix we simply multiply the minor of that element by the corresponding sign from the \(3\times 3\) array of signs.

Hence, for the matrix \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\), the cofactor corresponding to \(a_{23}\) is \[A_{23} = - \begin{vmatrix} 4 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = -1\] and the cofactor corresponding to \(a_{31}\) is \[A_{31} = + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 \end{vmatrix}=1.\]
